ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Really delved into fundamental concepts in political economy, foundations, new research. I think this course, more than others I've had so far, has helped me to really think historically, and to historicize the kinds of trends and themes one sees in research.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Rather than purely posing discussion questions for each week, it might be useful to have students also summarize the text to make sure that everyone is on the same page in understanding the argument and how effective it is.

I liked that many classes had a particular concept to unpack--price, property, wage, etc. It was also good to include the foundational readings (Marx, Polanyi, Wood). Class discussion was robust and expansive. A few of the weeks of reading could be maybe a little excessive. (Urban geography week--Self, Harvey, Gilmore comes to mind. Hard to complete that much reading in a week.) Maybe I'm a wimp, but when it's over 350 pages, it becomes very difficult to finish, especially with other classes' readings.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes-it was a good intensive course in political economy. I would warn them, though, to make sure they have enough time to devote to some of the weeks of reading.
